comment.author: 48296773@N03
comment._content: The Crooked House is a colloquial name for the Glynne Arms. A combination of nearby marl hole (clay quarry) and the underlying 30-foot seam of thick coal have led to subsidence contorting the building so great that pin-pong balls appear to roll uphill on the backs of the benches. Thus it has morphed from quarrymen's pub to a destination for dining and a walkers (and riders) drop in. It has a lovely warm fire on a winters day too! (I have no connection with publican or brewery...) . see also www.geograph.org.uk/photo/129423 I remember by granddad always wearing a black "wescut" and sleeves rolled up to the elbow. It was the universal Black Country look until the 1970s!
